The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Health (Paper C.P.-201 (30))on the subject of Birth Control, in which he stated that the question had again come before him in connection with the powers of Local Authori-ties to establish either (l) separate birthcontrol clinics, or (2) gynaecological clinicsat which advice and information as to contra-ceptive methods would be given to those whoattend. The Minister of Health stated that hewas advised that there is probably a need incertain areas for the establishment of gynaecol-ogical clinics, and he did not consider., there-fore, that- he would be justified in withholdingany Departmental sanction that may be necessaryfor the provision of such clinics by LocalAuthorities. But under the Public Health Actsthese clinics could be provided only for the reception of the sick, and he propose^, therefore,to Eake it a condition of his sanction -(i) that the clinics would be availableonly for women who are in need of medical advice and treatment forgynaecological conditions; and(ii) that advice on contraceptive methodswould be given only to married women who attend the clinics for medical advice or treatment and in whosecases pregnancy would be detrimenta 1to health.As regards the case of the birthcontrol clinic for expectant mothersand nursing mothers he proposed torefuse to sanction loans except on condition that contraceptive advicewould be given only in cases wherefurther pregnancies would be detrl-mental to health. The Cabinet approved the proposalsof the Minister of Health, and agreed with him that it is desir-able to maintain the position that without express directionsfrom Parliament the Governmentwill' not sanction the expendi-ture of public money for theprovision of facilities forgiving birth control advicepromiscuously to any woman who may ask for it. 4. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Labour (Paper CP.-219 (30))on the subject of Unemployment Finance. Afterpointing out that the amount of debt outstandingat the moment is.642,930,000, leaving 7,000,000borrowing powers still available, of which 6,000,000 is available for financing weeklyoutgoings from the Fund, the Minister askedauthority of the Cabinet to introduce a Billproviding for an extension of the borrowing powers to the extent of 20,000,000 and suggestedthat arrangements should be made to secure its passage into law before the House rises for the summer Recess.In the course of a discussion on both theeconomic and political aspects of the question,stress was laid on the importance of theGovernment spokesmen on the Bill being in aposition to indicate, if necessary, what theultimate policy of the Government was to render the Unemployment Fund solvent and to aveidperiodical increases in its borrowing powers.The Cabinet agreed - (a) That provision should be made inthe Bill for an extension of the borrowing powers to the extent of 10,000,000:(b) That the Bill should be examined by the Home Affairs Committee:(c) That arrangements should be madeto secure its passage into law before Parliament rises for the summer Recess:(d) That the Minister of Labour should circulate a Memorandum to the Cabinetgiving the figures and facts inregard to transitional benefit,including the benefits paid tomarried women, with a view tofurther consideration of thesubject. jHE LONDON NAVAL 5. The CaDi.net had before them a MemorandumTREATY BILL.by the First Lord of the Admiralty (Paper C.P.-(Previous 218 (30)) covering a draft London Naval TreatyReference:Cabinet 33 Bill. It was explained that, in view of the(30), Con-conclusion 4.) provisions of the London Naval Treaty for limita-tions (additional to those in the Treaties of washington Act, 1922) as to the displacement orarmament of Submarines and Airdraft Carriersit is necessary, before ratifying the Treaty, topass legislation authorising the Admiralty torefuse a licence to shipbuilding firms, when necessary for the purpose of securing the observance of these restrictions. This is doneby Section 1. In addition, Section 2 of theBill repeals Section 4 of the Treaties of"Washington Act, 1922, in which power was takento implement the Washington (Root) Treaty toprotect neutrals and non-combatants at sea intime of war, insofar as power was then taken to try and punish as if for an act of piracy anyperson in the service of any Power who violatedthe rules that were set out in Article 1 of the root Treaty.The Cabinet approved in principle the London Naval Treaty Bill and invited the First Lord of theAdmiralty to consult his legal advisers once more as to whetherit was really essential to passthis Bill before the ratification of the London Naval Treaty.The date of introduction of theBill, in the light of these enquiries, was left for arrangement between the First Lord of theAdmiralty and the Prime Minister,' SCOTLAND.6 . Atpresent, however, this information was two or three years old, and theMinister stated that she was con-suiting with the Secretary of Statefor Scotland as to the possibilityof obtaining more up to date infor-mation. It was also mentioned that a somewhat analogous problemon a small scale occurs in connec-tion with , - sugar beet growingin England, and the Ministry ofLabour had been attempting to check the influx of Irish labour by a special canvass of employersand a wide circulation of a leafletattached to the Memorandum.The subject was again postponed, pending thereceipt of new information which is being compiledunder the direction of the Secretary of State forScotland.The Prime Minister appealed to his colleagues,when this information is received, to give themost careful consideration to the whole question,which presented serious aspects from the point ofview of social conditions in Scotland. Thequestion of the date 'at which the amendmentsshould be discussed in the House of Commons was left to the Prime Minister and the President ofthe Board of Trade.-7- 2n nTHE ISLE OP MAN(CUSTOMS) BILL,1930.(previous reference:Cabinet 36(29), Con-clusion 2 and appendix.)by the Financial Secretary to the Treasury(CP .-222 (30)), circulated by direction ofthe Chancellor of the Exchequer, covering the isle of Man (Customs) Bill, 19 30, and explainingits principal provisions. The authority of theCabinet was requested to introduce the Bill andto proceed with it at once, subject to any drafting or other minor amendments which mightbe found necessary or desirable. In view of itsuncontroversial nature the Bill had not been referred to the Committee of Home Affairs.The Cabinet authorised theFinancial Secretary to theTreasury to introduce the isle of Man (Customs) bill and to proceed with it atonce, subject to any drafting or other amendments which mightbe found necessary or desirable. c233JjjgffLOYMENTPOLICY.public Works;3Cilities[ill, 19 30.[(previous reference-.Cabinet 35(50), Con-elusion 8.)9 . The Cabinet had before them a dra^t PublicWorks Facilities Bill, which had been approvedby the Panel of Ministers concerned with Unemploy-ment at their meeting on July 1, 19 30 (CP.-223(30)), together with explanatory notes on theGlauses .The Prime Minister made a report on certainenquiries he had made as to the attitude ofvarious elements in Parliament towards the bill and stated that co-operation in its passage would depend upon the Government being able to justifythat every item thereof was required as anemergency measure for dealing with Unemploymentduring the coming winter.Some discussion took place as to the effectof the Bill on Parliamentary business, and thePrime Minister explained that its passage wouldprobably involve Parliament remaining in sessionuntil towards the end of the week ending August9th.As regards the change involved in the standing orders of the House of Commons, the^Prime ministers aid he did not propose to ask the House to a'mehdthe Standing Orders but to add a new standing order which would come into operation only inconnection with business arising out of this Act.The Cabinet agreed (a) To approve the Public WorksFacilities Bill for introducetion in Parliament at theearliest date that the PrimeMinister could arrange forconsistently with other business:(b) That the Bill should be examined with the least possible delay byth.4 Committ ee of Horne Affairs, andthat after such examination it neednot await Cabinet approval before its introduction. If any question of principle arose during the examination by the Committeeof Home Affairs, the PrimeMinister would settle it withthose of his colleagues most closely concerned:(c) That the procedure in the Houseof Commons in regard to the Billshould be left to the PrimeMinister to arrange with a viewto its passage as rapidly aspossible.-10- INDIA.previous ionsReference:Cabinet 34(go), Con-conclusion 2.)10. The Secretary o^ State for India made a verbal report to the Cabinet regarding twoconferences which the Prime Minister and himself had held with the Leaders and.representatives ofthe Opposition Parties on the subject of theforthcoming Conference on India. He indicated that Parliamentary criticism of the Viceroy'forthcoming Statement in regard to the conference might be expected from the Conservative Party.The Viceroy was acting in full agreement with thehome Government..:. The political situation had beenreported to him and a reply was expected in thenear future. In reply to a question the Secretaryof State added later that the Viceroy would include- in his speech a statement to the effectthat if the Government's policy towards theConference elicited a favourable response, theleaders of the Congress Party who were at present under arrest would be released and the policy ofrepression which had been forced on the "government by breaches of the peace would be relaxed.The Prime Minister said that the subject wasnot at present ripe for any decision by theCabinet, but if the communication now expected from the Viceroy should render this necessaryhe would summon a special Meeting of the Cabinet.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,July 2,1930.
